McDavid (1985) notes that private crews use physical productivity bonuses and profit-sharing schemes. Coopers and Lybrand (1981) give examples where the decision to tender refuse collection services followed a period of negotiation which failed to secure changes in the payment scheme.

Competitive tendering requires the drawing up of a detailed specification of the work to be carried out and this is bound to facilitate the management and monitoring of resource utilisation. See National Audit Office (1987).

In terms of economic analysis, if goods or services are not supplied at minimum cost then 'productive efficiency' is violated. In this case it can be shown that 'allocative efficiency' is also violated and this means that someone can be made better off without anyone being made worse off by re-allocating resources in the economy. These arguments are spelled out in Dornberger and Piggott (1986) and Rees (1984, pp. 15-16).
